description: T.3 Oak - 35% Holistic crown reduction to suitable growth points (70% By Vol - HortLINK reduction) & deadwood.
decision_conditions: T.1 Oak - 2.5m Holistic crown reduction to suitable growth points, maintaining natural shape & form, remove all epicormic growth, deadwood & ivy, & install a sheet piled steel corrugated root barrier to a depth of 4m in the location shown on the attached plan.

The application to carry out a 35% crown reduction (70% by vol) in accordance with Hort-link pruning protocol is flawed. " "The results of the ODPM-sponsored research undertaken by the HortLINK at East Malling Research (Hipps, 2004) shows that pruning within arboricultural industry guidelines is ineffective in controlling water use. Only a crown reduction of over 70 per cent by volume, which equates to a 35 per cent crown reduction, has any effect and then it is for one season only (if that) and the reduced trees use more water in the following season (Hipps, 2004)." As the effect of such pruning at best lasts only one year - following which the tree's response creates an aggrevated water demand - the long term effect of such works would be to increase water demand on the soil and thereby cause further building damage.Lastly, it should be noted that the removal of the garage does not present a constraint to the installation of a root barrier as the owner has confirmed that the garage is to be removed to facilitate the pending extension anyway. Likewise the owner of No.176 has granted permission for access to her land in order to install the root barrier across her back garden as per the attached plan.

This application has been submitted in pursuant to conditions 8 and 10 of application 22/03680/FUL. Condition 8 reads: Details of the proposed extract ventilation system (including the extraction hood, internal fan, flexible couplings, three-stage filtration [grease filters, pre-filters and activated carbon filters], height of the extract duct above eaves level and anti-vibration mountings) shall be submitted to, and approved in writing by, the Local Planning Authority before construction commences. Particular consideration should be given to the high level discharge of kitchen extract air. The approved details shall thereafter be installed prior to the use of the premises and permanently maintained as such thereafter. Reference should be had to the DEFRA document 'Guidance on the control of odour and noise from commercial kitchen exhaust' available athttps://www.gov.uk/government/publications/guidance-on-the-control-of-odour-and-noise-from-commercial-kitchen-exhaust Note despite being withdrawn by DEFRA,Reason: To ensure that the development does not result in odour disturbance to neighbouring residents.Condition 10 reads: The development to which this permission relates shall not be commenced until a scheme to protect and enhance the nature conservation interest of the site has been submitted to and agreed in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development.Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with Policy G6 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. The submitted information has been reviewed and is considered satisfactory and hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.ProposalErection of hip to gable roof extension in one side with rear and partial side dormer, installation of 2nos front rooflights and 1no rooflight on top of flat roof.This application follows recently refused application 23/01243/HOU dated 04.07.2023 for the erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with installation of 1no. front rooflight to facilitate loft conversion which was refused for the following reason;1) The proposed development would be incongruous, of a monolithic appearance and jarring when viewed within the street scene and would not respect the character of the existing dwelling or the wider area. The proposed development is therefore contrary to Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012), the Residential Design SPD (2013) and the NPPF (2021).This reason for refusal would need to be addressed for this application to be successful.Consultation7 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Roof extensions can have a significant impact on the character of the streetscape both in individual cases or through the cumulative impact of several roof extensions within a street. This is particularly true where they are visually prominent within the street. Proposals to extend a hipped roof to a gable roof are not usually appropriate as they are often at odds with the existing character of a property. Policy guidance 39 of the residential design SPD states that Dormer windows should be designed so that they:-are set down from the ridge line of the existing roof by at least 500mm;-are set in from the sides and eaves of the roof by at least 500mm;-do not feature on the front slope of the roof (in most cases);-are designed to complement the character of the existing house and wider area;-match or line-up with any original windows below; and,-are not built in the style of a mansard roofThe original application proposed a full (double) hip to gable and this application proposes hip to gable to one side only. The proposed dormer has not been set down from the ridge and would now be visible beyond the original roof where no hip to gable has been proposed. This would result in a very clumsy roof form and would not be in keeping with other properties within the streescene and would detract from the appearance of the dwelling and wider area. It is noted that a fallback position of permitted development has not been demonstrated nor is it thought that the overall size of the proposed extension would be compliant with this legislation either with regards to volume. It is further noted that a proposed roof light would exceed the highest part of the original roof, contrary to Class C householder permitted development rights, such that the application scheme would not be permitted development.Overall, the proposed development is still considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The reason for refusal has therefore not been addressed.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officers Comments: While no Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021), Officers consider that the proposal should be able to meet the requirements of Policy D12(A). Were the application otherwise acceptable, a Fire Strategy would be secured by way of a planning condition. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
